title: 112_s1153
content: The Act titled "Federal Land Asset Inventory Reform Act of 2011" defines key terms. The Act titled "Federal Land Asset Inventory Reform Act of 2011" defines the term "cadastre" as an inventory of Federal land depicting physical features and boundaries through various data collection methods. The term "cadastre" includes a geodetic network, large scale maps, cadastral boundary overlay, parcel indexing system, and land data files. The term "cadastre" includes information for cross-referencing data files, detailing parcel use, value, assets, and infrastructure, and designating parcels for potential non-Federal ownership. Federal land refers to land owned by the government. Federal land is land under Federal Government jurisdiction, including buildings, crops, forests, resources, improvements, fixtures, and any interest in the land. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. CADASTRE OF FEDERAL LAND. The Secretary is required to develop a multipurpose cadastre of Federal land for land management, conservation, protection, and use. Cost-sharing agreements with States can be made to include non-Federal land in the cadastre, with the Federal share not exceeding 50 percent. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Natural Resources within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report to the Committee on Natural Resources and the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources describes existing land inventories authorized by Federal law, their statutory authorization, and the Federal Government's expenditures for fiscal year 2010. It also includes any inventories that would be eliminated or consolidated into the cadastre authorized under the Act. The report outlines the use of existing land inventories by State or local governments to identify Federal land, cost-savings from eliminating duplicative inventories, and recommendations for legislation to enhance efficiency. The Secretary shall participate in establishing standards for geospatial information interoperability and coordinate with the Federal Geographic Data Committee. The cadastre must comply with standards, be interoperable with the Federal Real Property Profile, integrate with State and local government activities, and utilize private sector contracts for product provision. Contracts for surveying and mapping services under paragraph (1)(E) must be provided to develop the cadastre in compliance with standards and utilizing private sector contracts.
